class_notes: This course uses the social practices linked with love, marriage, and sexuality as a lens through which to view the cultural values, legal systems, and lived experiences of ordinary women and men in Renaissance Europe (1400-1600). One of our goals is historicize love and sex: to understand the ways in which seemingly timeless emotions were expressed and experienced differently across historical periods. Topics include sexual intimacy both inside and outside marriage; female agency and changing gender roles in household and neighborhood; sex work, sexual violence, and same-sex relations; reproductive labor and sexually transmitted disease; and complex links between sex and power. Readings include primary sources in translation. Grading based on weekly class participation; rotating discussion leaders; in-class presentation; short primary source analysis; several Canvas posts; research proposal, annotated bibliography, and research paper (4500 words) using primary sources.
